elements.content: We report the structures of six anionic, isomorphous metal–organic frameworks [Ln­(bpdc)2 –]­[NH2(CH3)2 +], where Ln = La, Ce, Nd, Eu, Gd, Er, and bpdc2– = biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate = –O2C­(C6H4)2CO2 –. The Ln­(III) metal centers exhibit eight-coordinate binding to six different bpdc2– ligands (four of which are μ-2 bridging and two are bidentate) and the framework is charge-balanced by a dimethylammonium cation. The materials all possess the same 3D structure and crystallize in the orthorhombic space group Pbcn. All exhibit thermal stability up to ca. 300 °C and decompose to Ln2O3 after 800 °C. The Eu-based structure exhibits strong fluorescence in the 612–620 nm range. These materials significantly expand the known chemistry and luminescence of the less studied f-block metal–organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text: We report the structures of six anionic, isomorphous metal-organic frameworks [Ln(bpdc)2 -][NH2(CH3)2 +], where Ln = La, Ce, Nd, Eu, Gd, Er, and bpdc2- = biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylate = -O2C(C6H4)2CO2 -. The Ln(III) metal centers exhibit eight-coordinate binding to six different bpdc2- ligands (four of which are μ-2 bridging and two are bidentate) and the framework is charge-balanced by a dimethylammonium cation. The materials all possess the same 3D structure and crystallize in the orthorhombic space group Pbcn. All exhibit thermal stability up to ca. 300 °C and decompose to Ln2O3 after 800 °C. The Eu-based structure exhibits strong fluorescence in the 612-620 nm range. These materials significantly expand the known chemistry and luminescence of the less studied f-block metal-organic frameworks.

elements.content:
The structures of six anionic lanthanide metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have been reported and characterized. The MOFs are isomorphous, and the europium-based MOF is luminescent.

Introduction

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous inorganic–organic hybrid materials that have been researched for their potential applications in ion exchange, gas storage, catalysis, and sensing. The various metal and linker combinations are seemingly endless and have resulted in thousands of new materials with different geometries and functionalities. Lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) have garnered attention recently due in large part to their luminescent properties. The lanthanides, or rare earth metals, share a number of common characteristics. They are often in the +3 oxidation state, have similar ionic radii (0.85 to 1.06 Å), and exhibit large coordination numbers. It is due to these properties that Ln-MOFs for a given linker and synthesis conditions are often isomorphous.
elements.clean_text:
The structures of six anionic lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been reported and characterized. The MOFs are isomorphous, and the europium-based MOF is luminescent.

Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous inorganic-organic hybrid materials that have been researched for their potential applications in ion exchange, gas storage, catalysis, and sensing. The various metal and linker combinations are seemingly endless and have resulted in thousands of new materials with different geometries and functionalities. Lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) have garnered attention recently due in large part to their luminescent properties. The lanthanides, or rare earth metals, share a number of common characteristics. They are often in the +3 oxidation state, have similar ionic radii (0.85 to 1.06 Å), and exhibit large coordination numbers. It is due to these properties that Ln-MOFs for a given linker and synthesis conditions are often isomorphous.

elements.content: The lanthanide ions Eu­(III) and Tb­(III) are known to luminesce due to electronic f–f transitions in the visible region. These ions have excited levels at slightly lower energy than the excited triplets typical of ligands containing π-delocalized systems. The luminescence of Eu­(III) and Tb­(III) can be augmented with a conjugated linker. Conjugated linkers are able to absorb light energy and transfer to the lanthanide metal in a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) process, followed by emission from the metal. The combinations of Eu­(III) and Tb­(III) and conjugated linkers have expanded the chemistry of luminescent MOFs. The conjugated ligand biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate [bpdc2–, –O2C­(C6H4)2CO2 –] has been well-studied as a MOF ligand and is known to give rise to LMCT. Several series of isomorphous lanthanide MOFs with the bpdc2– ligand have been reported in recent years.
elements.clean_text: The lanthanide ions Eu(III) and Tb(III) are known to luminesce due to electronic f-f transitions in the visible region. These ions have excited levels at slightly lower energy than the excited triplets typical of ligands containing π-delocalized systems. The luminescence of Eu(III) and Tb(III) can be augmented with a conjugated linker. Conjugated linkers are able to absorb light energy and transfer to the lanthanide metal in a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) process, followed by emission from the metal. The combinations of Eu(III) and Tb(III) and conjugated linkers have expanded the chemistry of luminescent MOFs. The conjugated ligand biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylate [bpdc2-, -O2C(C6H4)2CO2 -] has been well-studied as a MOF ligand and is known to give rise to LMCT. Several series of isomorphous lanthanide MOFs with the bpdc2- ligand have been reported in recent years.

elements.content: A luminescent Tb­(III)-based MOF, DUT-101 (Dalian University of Technology, [Tb­(bpdc)2 –]­[NH2(CH3)2 +]) was recently reported. The material is a selective turn-off sensor for UO2 2+ ions, although this species is typically carbonated in water and thus neutral or anionic. Ye and co-workers demonstrated the fabrication of a fluorescent test paper incorporated with DUT-101 that is quenched after contact with aqueous UO2 2+ ions. The UO2 2+ ions are thought to disrupt the LMCT process and result in luminescence quenching. The application of luminescence, along with the intrinsic pore volume of metal–organic frameworks, make such materials promising real-time sensors.
elements.clean_text: A luminescent Tb(III)-based MOF, DUT-101 (Dalian University of Technology, [Tb(bpdc)2 -][NH2(CH3)2 +]) was recently reported. The material is a selective turn-off sensor for UO2 2+ ions, although this species is typically carbonated in water and thus neutral or anionic. Ye and co-workers demonstrated the fabrication of a fluorescent test paper incorporated with DUT-101 that is quenched after contact with aqueous UO2 2+ ions. The UO2 2+ ions are thought to disrupt the LMCT process and result in luminescence quenching. The application of luminescence, along with the intrinsic pore volume of metal-organic frameworks, make such materials promising real-time sensors.

elements.content: Here, we discuss the structures of six new lanthanide metal–organic frameworks. The materials possess negatively charged [Ln­(bpdc)2 –] (Ln = La, Ce, Nd, Eu, Gd, Er) metal–organic frameworks that are charge-balanced by dimethylammonium. The crystal structures of four of the six materials were solved by single crystal XRD, and all were characterized by PXRD (powder X-ray diffraction), thermal characterization, vibrational spectroscopy, and photoluminescence.
elements.clean_text: Here, we discuss the structures of six new lanthanide metal-organic frameworks. The materials possess negatively charged [Ln(bpdc)2 -] (Ln = La, Ce, Nd, Eu, Gd, Er) metal-organic frameworks that are charge-balanced by dimethylammonium. The crystal structures of four of the six materials were solved by single crystal XRD, and all were characterized by PXRD (powder X-ray diffraction), thermal characterization, vibrational spectroscopy, and photoluminescence.

elements.content: Lanthanum­(III) nitrate hexahydrate [La­(NO3)3·6H2O, Alfa Aesar, 99%], cerium­(III) nitrate hexahydrate [Ce­(NO3)3·6H2O, Spectrum, 99%], neodymium­(III) nitrate hexahydrate [Nd­(NO3)3·6H2O, Alfa Aesar, 99.9%], europium­(III) nitrate hexahydrate [Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O, Strem Chemicals, 99.9%], gadolinium­(III) nitrate hexahydrate [Gd­(NO3)3·6H2O, Strem Chemicals, 99.9%], erbium­(III) nitrate pentahydrate [Er­(NO3)3·5H2O, Acros Organics, 99.9%], 4-(4′-carboxy)­phenylbenzoic acid [HO2C­(C6H4)2CO2H, Combi-Blocks, 98%], and N,N-dimethylformamide [(CH3)2NCHO, Macron Fine Chemicals, Analytical Reagent] were all used as-received.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Reagents

Lanthanum(III) nitrate hexahydrate [La(NO3)3⋅6H2O, Alfa Aesar, 99%], cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate [Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O, Spectrum, 99%], neodymium(III) nitrate hexahydrate [Nd(NO3)3⋅6H2O, Alfa Aesar, 99.9%], europium(III) nitrate hexahydrate [Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O, Strem Chemicals, 99.9%], gadolinium(III) nitrate hexahydrate [Gd(NO3)3⋅6H2O, Strem Chemicals, 99.9%], erbium(III) nitrate pentahydrate [Er(NO3)3⋅5H2O, Acros Organics, 99.9%], 4-(4'-carboxy)phenylbenzoic acid [HO2C(C6H4)2CO2H, Combi-Blocks, 98%], and N,N-dimethylformamide [(CH3)2NCHO, Macron Fine Chemicals, Analytical Reagent] were all used as-received.

elements.content: [Ln­(bpdc)2 –]­[NH2(CH3)2 +] (Ln = La, Ce, Nd, Eu, Gd, Er, which we denote as SLUG-43, -44, -45, -46, -47, and -48, respectively, for the University of California, Santa Cruz-structure number) were synthesized under solvothermal conditions. A mixture of Ln­(NO3)3·xH2O (0.200 g), 4,4′-H2-bpdc (0.226 g), and 10.0 mL DMF was stirred until homogeneous, transferred into an autoclave, and heated statically under autogenous pressure for 3 d at 140 to 150 °C, then slow cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min. After vacuum filtering and rinsing with ethanol, lustrous, block-shaped crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) were collected among a powder of smaller crystals of the same phase.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

[Ln(bpdc)2 -][NH2(CH3)2 +] (Ln = La, Ce, Nd, Eu, Gd, Er, which we denote as SLUG-43, -44, -45, -46, -47, and -48, respectively, for the University of California, Santa Cruz-structure number) were synthesized under solvothermal conditions. A mixture of Ln(NO3)3⋅xH2O (0.200 g), 4,4'-H2-bpdc (0.226 g), and 10.0 mL DMF was stirred until homogeneous, transferred into an autoclave, and heated statically under autogenous pressure for 3 d at 140 to 150 °C, then slow cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min. After vacuum filtering and rinsing with ethanol, lustrous, block-shaped crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) were collected among a powder of smaller crystals of the same phase.

elements.content: Pale yellow, almost colorless, crystals of SLUG-43 (La), SLUG-44 (Ce), SLUG-46 (Eu), and SLUG-47 (Gd) (dimensions are given in ) were secured to a Mitegen micromount using Paratone oil. Their SCXRD data was collected at 100 K using a Rigaku Oxford Diffraction (ROD) Synergy-S X-ray diffractometer equipped with a HyPix-6000HE hybrid photon counting (HPC) detector and microfocused Mo–Kα1 radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). For all samples, data collection strategies to ensure completeness and desired redundancy were determined using CrysAlisPro. Data processing was performed using CrysAlisPro and included numerical absorption corrections determined via face-indexing for all samples, applied using the SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. All structures were solved via intrinsic phasing methods using ShelXT and refined using ShelXL in the Olex2 graphical user interface. Space groups were unambiguously verified by PLATON. The final structural refinement included anisotropic temperature factors on all non-hydrogen atoms. All hydrogen atoms were attached via the riding model at calculated positions using suitable HFIX commands.
elements.clean_text:
Instrumental Analysis

Pale yellow, almost colorless, crystals of SLUG-43 (La), SLUG-44 (Ce), SLUG-46 (Eu), and SLUG-47 (Gd) (dimensions are given in ) were secured to a Mitegen micromount using Paratone oil. Their SCXRD data was collected at 100 K using a Rigaku Oxford Diffraction (ROD) Synergy-S X-ray diffractometer equipped with a HyPix-6000HE hybrid photon counting (HPC) detector and microfocused Mo-Kα1 radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). For all samples, data collection strategies to ensure completeness and desired redundancy were determined using CrysAlisPro. Data processing was performed using CrysAlisPro and included numerical absorption corrections determined via face-indexing for all samples, applied using the SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. All structures were solved via intrinsic phasing methods using ShelXT and refined using ShelXL in the Olex2 graphical user interface. Space groups were unambiguously verified by PLATON. The final structural refinement included anisotropic temperature factors on all non-hydrogen atoms. All hydrogen atoms were attached via the riding model at calculated positions using suitable HFIX commands.

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained on a Rigaku Miniflex II Plus diffractometer with Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) from 2° to 35° or 60° (2θ) at a rate of 2° per minute and a step size of 0.02°. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a TA Q500 Thermoanalyzer. Samples were heated in a platinum pan at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min under nitrogen flow. The samples for ex situ variable temperature (VT-) PXRD were heated in a tube furnace to the designated temperature at a rate of 2 °C/min in air. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of the materials was collected on a PerkinElmer spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Steady-state photoluminescence spectrum was obtained at room temperature on an Edinburgh Instruments FLS980 spectrophotometer. Absolute PLQE measurements of both bulk and microscopic crystals were performed on FLS 920 spectrophotometer with an integrating sphere (BaSO4 coating) using single photon counting mode. The focal length of the monochromator was 300 mm. Samples were excited at 320 nm (Eu-bpdc) using a 450 W xenon lamp with 3 mm excitation slit width and detected by a Hamamatsu R928p photomultiplier tube. The emission was obtained using 0.2 nm scan step, 0.2 s scan dwell time, and 0.1 mm emission slit width. The PLQEs were calculated by the equation: φ = kδ/kδ, where kδ is the number of emitted photons and kδ is the number of absorbed photons. CHN elemental analysis was performed on samples of SLUG-43 (La) and SLUG-48 (Er) as representative examples. SLUG-43: calculated (%), C 54.14, H 3.64, N 2.10; observed (%), C 51.20, H 3.62, N 2.12. SLUG-48: calculated (%), C 51.93, H 3.49, N 2.02; observed (%), C 50.73, H 3.52, N 2.01.

elements.content: SLUG-43 through 48 were synthesized solvothermally in high yield [80% to 89% based on Ln­(III)] at a synthesis temperature range of 140 to 150 °C. Below this optimal temperature range, no crystalline product formed. Longer synthesis times resulted in higher crystallinity and slightly higher yield. The crystals were colorless blocks () among a powder of the same phase (Figure S1). Single crystal structures of the MOFs based on La, Ce, Eu, and Gd (SLUG-43, -44, -46, and -47, respectively) were obtained and solved ( and S2–S4). The crystal data for these structures are summarized in . The experimental PXRDs match the theoretical PXRD calculated from the single crystal data, verifying that this series of MOFs is isostructural. The similarity of the PXRD patterns for SLUG-45 and -48 (based on Nd and Er, respectively, ) support that they are isomorphous despite forming crystals too small for SCXRD analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

SLUG-43 through 48 were synthesized solvothermally in high yield [80% to 89% based on Ln(III)] at a synthesis temperature range of 140 to 150 °C. Below this optimal temperature range, no crystalline product formed. Longer synthesis times resulted in higher crystallinity and slightly higher yield. The crystals were colorless blocks () among a powder of the same phase (Figure S1). Single crystal structures of the MOFs based on La, Ce, Eu, and Gd (SLUG-43, -44, -46, and -47, respectively) were obtained and solved ( and S2-S4). The crystal data for these structures are summarized in . The experimental PXRDs match the theoretical PXRD calculated from the single crystal data, verifying that this series of MOFs is isostructural. The similarity of the PXRD patterns for SLUG-45 and -48 (based on Nd and Er, respectively, ) support that they are isomorphous despite forming crystals too small for SCXRD analysis.

elements.content: The SCXRD studies reveal that the asymmetric unit of SLUG-43–48 contains one Ln­(III) ion, two bpdc2– ligands, and one dimethylammonium cation. The Ln­(III) ion is eight-coordinated by the oxygens from six different bpdc2– ligands in a distorted square antiprismatic coordination geometry. The average Ln–O bond distance is 2.44(6) Å, well within the covalent range based on a search of the Cambridge Structural Database. The ligand bpdc2– is known to adopt up to seven different coordination modes. In the present MOFs, all bpdc2– ligands exhibit the same type of binding mode (). One end of the ligand participates in η2 binding to one Ln­(III) ion, while the other end μ-2 bridges between two Ln­(III) ions, creating a three-dimensional framework. The Ln­(III) ions are independent with no inorganic connectivity but are centered about layers in the yz plane (B). The dimethylammonium cations are electrostatically coordinated to each Ln­(III) ion, balancing the net negative charge from each [Ln3+(bpdc2–)2]− unit.
elements.clean_text: The SCXRD studies reveal that the asymmetric unit of SLUG-43-48 contains one Ln(III) ion, two bpdc2- ligands, and one dimethylammonium cation. The Ln(III) ion is eight-coordinated by the oxygens from six different bpdc2- ligands in a distorted square antiprismatic coordination geometry. The average Ln-O bond distance is 2.44(6) Å, well within the covalent range based on a search of the Cambridge Structural Database. The ligand bpdc2- is known to adopt up to seven different coordination modes. In the present MOFs, all bpdc2- ligands exhibit the same type of binding mode (). One end of the ligand participates in η2 binding to one Ln(III) ion, while the other end μ-2 bridges between two Ln(III) ions, creating a three-dimensional framework. The Ln(III) ions are independent with no inorganic connectivity but are centered about layers in the yz plane (B). The dimethylammonium cations are electrostatically coordinated to each Ln(III) ion, balancing the net negative charge from each [Ln3+(bpdc2-)2]- unit.

elements.content: All six materials have very similar IR spectra, owing to their isomorphous topology (). Broad N–H stretching bands are visible centered around ∼3130 and 3400 cm–1 due to the dimethylammonium countercations. Four sharp peaks in the 1400 to 1650 cm–1 region are attributed to (CO)2 stretching from the carboxylate in the bpdc2– ligands. The sharp peak at ∼770 cm–1 is due to the characteristic C–H deformation of 1,4-disubstituted aromatics.
elements.clean_text:
Vibrational Spectroscopy

All six materials have very similar IR spectra, owing to their isomorphous topology (). Broad N-H stretching bands are visible centered around ~3130 and 3400 cm-1 due to the dimethylammonium countercations. Four sharp peaks in the 1400 to 1650 cm-1 region are attributed to (CO)2 stretching from the carboxylate in the bpdc2- ligands. The sharp peak at ~770 cm-1 is due to the characteristic C-H deformation of 1,4-disubstituted aromatics.

elements.content: SLUG-46 (Eu) begins to decompose at approximately 300 °C (A). The first mass loss of 19.4% corresponds to a loss of dimethylammonium and likely the hydrocarbon portion of one of the linkers, with a theoretical mass loss of 19.7%. The VT-PXRD shows a low angle peak with two higher order reflections after the sample was heated to 375 °C (B). It is possible that the Eu polyhedra have condensed into a layered structure. FTIR of this sample (Figure S6) shows the partial loss of the peaks at 3100 and 1650 cm–1, corresponding to N–H and (CO)2 stretching, respectively. The second decomposition event at ∼400 °C of 35.8% mass loss agrees well with the loss of an additional bpdc2– ligand (theoretical: 35.4%). The final decomposition event at ∼600 °C of 18.5% mass loss agrees with the loss of the remaining organic (theoretical: 18.9%). As expected, the final solid is Eu2O3 (ICDD PDF # 00–032–0380), confirmed by both PXRD after TGA heating and VT-PXRD (B, top pattern). The other SLUG-43–48 materials decompose similarly (Figures S7–S11).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Characterization

SLUG-46 (Eu) begins to decompose at approximately 300 °C (A). The first mass loss of 19.4% corresponds to a loss of dimethylammonium and likely the hydrocarbon portion of one of the linkers, with a theoretical mass loss of 19.7%. The VT-PXRD shows a low angle peak with two higher order reflections after the sample was heated to 375 °C (B). It is possible that the Eu polyhedra have condensed into a layered structure. FTIR of this sample (Figure S6) shows the partial loss of the peaks at 3100 and 1650 cm-1, corresponding to N-H and (CO)2 stretching, respectively. The second decomposition event at ~400 °C of 35.8% mass loss agrees well with the loss of an additional bpdc2- ligand (theoretical: 35.4%). The final decomposition event at ~600 °C of 18.5% mass loss agrees with the loss of the remaining organic (theoretical: 18.9%). As expected, the final solid is Eu2O3 (ICDD PDF # 00-032-0380), confirmed by both PXRD after TGA heating and VT-PXRD (B, top pattern). The other SLUG-43-48 materials decompose similarly (Figures S7-S11).

elements.content: The Eu­(III)-based MOF, SLUG-46, exhibits intense luminescence in the visible red-orange region (B and ). These emission bands are due to 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1, 2, 4) electronic transitions. The 5D0 → 7F3 transition is weakly observed at 660 nm. These electronic transitions are known to be the most notable for Eu­(III) complexes. The intense 5D0 → 7F2 transition is hypersensitive and indicates that Eu­(III) is not at a site with a center of symmetry. SLUG-46 displays a quantum efficiency of 2.11%, which is relatively low compared to other Eu­(III) compounds. As expected, none of the SLUG-43 (La), -44 (Ce), -45 (Nd), -47 (Gd), or -48 (Er) materials were fluorescent. The photoluminescence of SLUG-46 is quenched after the material is heated to 375 °C (Figure S7). As the organic is evolved, the LMCT process is likely disrupted and, as a result, Eu­(III) no longer emits light.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence

The Eu(III)-based MOF, SLUG-46, exhibits intense luminescence in the visible red-orange region (B and ). These emission bands are due to 5D0 → 7F J  (J = 1, 2, 4) electronic transitions. The 5D0 → 7F3 transition is weakly observed at 660 nm. These electronic transitions are known to be the most notable for Eu(III) complexes. The intense 5D0 → 7F2 transition is hypersensitive and indicates that Eu(III) is not at a site with a center of symmetry. SLUG-46 displays a quantum efficiency of 2.11%, which is relatively low compared to other Eu(III) compounds. As expected, none of the SLUG-43 (La), -44 (Ce), -45 (Nd), -47 (Gd), or -48 (Er) materials were fluorescent. The photoluminescence of SLUG-46 is quenched after the material is heated to 375 °C (Figure S7). As the organic is evolved, the LMCT process is likely disrupted and, as a result, Eu(III) no longer emits light.

elements.content: Six new Ln-MOF structures have been fully characterized and are isomorphous, exhibiting similar PXRD patterns, FTIR spectra, and thermal behavior. This work expands the chemistry of lanthanide MOFs. The transition to a layered material opens up the possible design of extended inorganic–organic hybrids for greater stability and modification of properties. SLUG-46, the Eu­(III)-containing MOF, is a potential sensing material due to its photoluminescent properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Six new Ln-MOF structures have been fully characterized and are isomorphous, exhibiting similar PXRD patterns, FTIR spectra, and thermal behavior. This work expands the chemistry of lanthanide MOFs. The transition to a layered material opens up the possible design of extended inorganic-organic hybrids for greater stability and modification of properties. SLUG-46, the Eu(III)-containing MOF, is a potential sensing material due to its photoluminescent properties.

cln_elements.content: [Ln­(bpdc)2 –]­[NH2(CH3)2 +] (Ln = La, Ce, Nd, Eu, Gd, Er, which we denote as SLUG-43, -44, -45, -46, -47, and -48, respectively, for the University of California, Santa Cruz-structure number) were synthesized under solvothermal conditions. A mixture of Ln­(NO3)3·xH2O (0.200 g), 4,4′-H2-bpdc (0.226 g), and 10.0 mL DMF was stirred until homogeneous, transferred into an autoclave, and heated statically under autogenous pressure for 3 d at 140 to 150 °C, then slow cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min. After vacuum filtering and rinsing with ethanol, lustrous, block-shaped crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) were collected among a powder of smaller crystals of the same phase.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

[Ln(bpdc)2 -][NH2(CH3)2 +] (Ln = La, Ce, Nd, Eu, Gd, Er, which we denote as SLUG-43, -44, -45, -46, -47, and -48, respectively, for the University of California, Santa Cruz-structure number) were synthesized under solvothermal conditions. A mixture of Ln(NO3)3⋅xH2O (0.200 g), 4,4'-H2-bpdc (0.226 g), and 10.0 mL DMF was stirred until homogeneous, transferred into an autoclave, and heated statically under autogenous pressure for 3 d at 140 to 150 °C, then slow cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min. After vacuum filtering and rinsing with ethanol, lustrous, block-shaped crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) were collected among a powder of smaller crystals of the same phase.

The VT-PXRD shows a low angle peak with two higher order reflections after the sample was heated to 375 °C (B). It is possible that the Eu polyhedra have condensed into a layered structure. The other SLUG-43–48 materials decompose similarly (Figures S7–S11).

Thermal ellipsoids are calculated at 50% probability.
